timeline.bodyText: Is there a chance that the header gets written after the TraceContext has been recycled?
timeline.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: This send method returns a callback that we wrap and the span is ended only when the callback's onCompletion method is called, so I can't see how...
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
What I would do is to have a ThreadLocal<RecordHeader>
Then you can do :
RecordHeader header = headerThreadLocal.get();
span.getTraceContext().fillOutgoingTraceParentBinaryHeader(header.value());
This minimizes allocations, as you don't have to allocate a Header each time, the TraceContext object does not get bigger in size and you also don't have to allocate a byte[] for the value. Additionally, there's no risk of using the value returned by span.getTraceContext().getOutgoingTraceParentBinaryHeader() at a wrong point in time.
The ThreadLocal works because after the send method got invoked, the header has already been serialized and sent out of process, thus it's safe to be re-used afterwards.

replies.bodyText:
The use of binary headers is relatively rare but adding the outgoingBinaryHeader variable increases the memory consumption of each object in the pool.

It's 29 bytes. What we can do is lazily create the array only when used for the first time, so it will take this space only where used.

Any chance to use write the value to thread-local-buffered byte arrays?

See the answer above- in Kafka another thread ends the span. It is possible that the thread sending the record will handle the send of another one before completion.
